elements.content: Two porous cobal–organic frameworks showing threefold interpenetration of pillared-layer structures, constructed from two-dimensional (2D) neutral metal–carboxylate layers and neutral bis-pyridyl-bis-amide pillars, were hydro(solvo)thermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound {[Co2(thdc)2(bpda)2(DMF)]·2DMF} n (1, thdc = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate; bpda = N,N′-bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide) adopts a uninodal 6-connected three-dimensional (3D) framework with a {412·63}-pcu topology in which 2D rhomboid-like 44-sql Co–thdc layers are pillared by bpda ligands. While compound {[Co3(btc)2(bpda)3]·2DMF·9H2O} n (2, btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) is composed of a binodal (3,4)-connected 3D framework with a (63)2(64·8·10)3 topology that can be described in terms of two building subunitsa 2D porous honeycomb-like 63-hcb Co–btc layer and a bpda pillar. An in-depth analysis showed that the mesh size of the metal–carboxylate layer, in addition to the pillar length, is highly correlated with the degree of interpenetration in the pillared-layer framework. The structural characteristics of frameworks 1 and 2 fully support this relationship.

Compound {[Co2(thdc)2(bpda)2(DMF)]⋅2DMF} n  (1, thdc = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylate; bpda = N,N'-bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide) adopts a uninodal 6-connected three-dimensional (3D) framework with a {412⋅63}-pcu topology in which 2D rhomboid-like 44-sql Co-thdc layers are pillared by bpda ligands. While compound {[Co3(btc)2(bpda)3]⋅2DMF⋅9H2O} n  (2, btc = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) is composed of a binodal (3,4)-connected 3D framework with a (63)2(64⋅8⋅10)3 topology that can be described in terms of two building subunitsa 2D porous honeycomb-like 63-hcb Co-btc layer and a bpda pillar. An in-depth analysis showed that the mesh size of the metal-carboxylate layer, in addition to the pillar length, is highly correlated with the degree of interpenetration in the pillared-layer framework. The structural characteristics of frameworks 1 and 2 fully support this relationship.

Their structural characteristics fully support the high correlation between the degree of interpenetration and the mesh size of the layers.

elements.content: Research on porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable interest in the past decade because of their intriguing network topologies and tunable host–guest interactions, making them potential candidates for specific gas adsorption and separation, molecular recognition and sensing, catalysis, drug delivery, and related processes. The generation of porous MOFs can be achieved by applying an approach involving a two-ligand assembly system, since an isoreticular 3D porous framework can be considered to have a pillared-layer structure in which the 2D metal–carboxylate layered motifs are pillared by (rigid) linear bis-pyridyl linkers (Scheme ). This provides a simple route to preparing desired porous frameworks with adjustable pore sizes and tunable structural properties by simply adjusting the length of the linear ligands or by changing the multicarboxylate moieties. As the length of the bridging ligands is increased, MOFs usually possess network interpenetration characteristics that tends to diminish the porosity. Unfortunately, interpenetration is difficult to avoid because not only are large free voids in present in a single network, but different networks also bear translational symmetry and are therefore equivalent within the bulk structure. Therefore, controlling interpenetration is of utmost importance. For pillared-layer porous MOFs, the influence of pillar length on the degree of interpenetration has been documented. However, controlling the degree of interpenetration by adjusting the mesh size of the metal–carboxylate layer has not been systematically studied. The findings reported herein indicate that the mesh size of the metal–carboxylate (M–O2C) layer can have a significant impact on the degree of interpenetration in porous MOFs. In addition, two new threefold pillared-layer cobalt–organic frameworks were successfully synthesized and their structural characteristics fully support the high correlation between the degree of interpenetration and the mesh size of the layers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Research on porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable interest in the past decade because of their intriguing network topologies and tunable host-guest interactions, making them potential candidates for specific gas adsorption and separation, molecular recognition and sensing, catalysis, drug delivery, and related processes. The generation of porous MOFs can be achieved by applying an approach involving a two-ligand assembly system, since an isoreticular 3D porous framework can be considered to have a pillared-layer structure in which the 2D metal-carboxylate layered motifs are pillared by (rigid) linear bis-pyridyl linkers (Scheme ). This provides a simple route to preparing desired porous frameworks with adjustable pore sizes and tunable structural properties by simply adjusting the length of the linear ligands or by changing the multicarboxylate moieties. As the length of the bridging ligands is increased, MOFs usually possess network interpenetration characteristics that tends to diminish the porosity. Unfortunately, interpenetration is difficult to avoid because not only are large free voids in present in a single network, but different networks also bear translational symmetry and are therefore equivalent within the bulk structure. Therefore, controlling interpenetration is of utmost importance. For pillared-layer porous MOFs, the influence of pillar length on the degree of interpenetration has been documented. However, controlling the degree of interpenetration by adjusting the mesh size of the metal-carboxylate layer has not been systematically studied. The findings reported herein indicate that the mesh size of the metal-carboxylate (M-O2C) layer can have a significant impact on the degree of interpenetration in porous MOFs. In addition, two new threefold pillared-layer cobalt-organic frameworks were successfully synthesized and their structural characteristics fully support the high correlation between the degree of interpenetration and the mesh size of the layers.

elements.content: Chemical reagents were purchased commercially and used as received without further purification. N,N′-Bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpda) was prepared according to the literature method. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Paragon 100 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr discs in the 4000–400 cm–1 region; abbreviations used for the IR bands are w = weak, m = medium, s = strong, b = broad. Elemental analyses were carried out on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TGA) analyses were performed under nitrogen with a PerkinElmer TGA-7 TG analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were recorded on a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer at 40 kV, 30 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a step size of 0.02° in θ and a scan speed of 1 s per step size.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instruments

Chemical reagents were purchased commercially and used as received without further purification. N,N'-Bis(4-pyridinyl)-1,4-benzenedicarboxamide (bpda) was prepared according to the literature method. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Paragon 100 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr discs in the 4000-400 cm-1 region; abbreviations used for the IR bands are w = weak, m = medium, s = strong, b = broad. Elemental analyses were carried out on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TGA) analyses were performed under nitrogen with a PerkinElmer TGA-7 TG analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were recorded on a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer at 40 kV, 30 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a step size of 0.02° in θ and a scan speed of 1 s per step size.

elements.content: A mixture of CoCl2·6H2O (24.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2thdc, 17.2 mg, 0.10 mmol), bpda (31.9 mg, 0.10 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 7 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bomb and heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then slowly cooled to 30 °C. Reddish prismatic crystals of 1 were isolated on a filter, washed with water, and then dried in air (29.4 mg, yield 46%). Anal. Calcd for C57H53Co2N11O15S2: C, 52.10; H, 4.07; N, 11.72%. elements.content: Data collection for 1 and 2 was performed on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer and on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer, respectively. All diffractometers were equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Starting models for structure refinement were found using direct methods (SHELXS-97), and the structural data were refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the WINGX and SHELX-97 program packages. Non-hydrogen atoms were found from the different Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters except where noted. In modeling 1, one bpda ligand was found to be disordered over two occupied sites with refined site occupancy factors of 0.716 and 0.284. The coordinated DMF and one lattice DMF molecule were treated disorderedly over two locations, which were refined isotropically with site occupancy factors of 0.540 and 0.460. In 2, the amide oxygen atom of the bpda ligand was treated disorderedly over two occupied sites with refined site occupancy factors of 0.65 and 0.35, respectively, which were refined isotropically. The guest solvent molecules in the porous structures are disordered and cannot be identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove the diffraction contribution from these solvents, resulting in a set of solvent free diffraction intensities. The calculations indicate the presence of a 512 e/unit cell which can be attributed to two DMF and nine water molecules per formula, and the results are included in the crystallographic CIF file (D calc, F 000, and molecular weight). Carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and were refined as riding atoms. Nitrogen-bound hydrogen atoms were first located on difference Fourier maps, and then fixed at the calculated positions and were included in the final refinement. Isotropic displacement parameters of all hydrogen atoms were derived from the parent atoms. The number of guest solvent molecules given in the formula for 1 and 2 was consistent with the single-crystal X-ray diffraction results, respectively. Experimental details for X-ray data collection and the refinements are summarized in Table .

Crystal Structure Determination

Data collection for 1 and 2 was performed on a Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer and on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer, respectively. All diffractometers were equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Starting models for structure refinement were found using direct methods (SHELXS-97), and the structural data were refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 using the WINGX and SHELX-97 program packages. Non-hydrogen atoms were found from the different Fourier maps and refined with anisotropic displacement parameters except where noted. In modeling 1, one bpda ligand was found to be disordered over two occupied sites with refined site occupancy factors of 0.716 and 0.284. The coordinated DMF and one lattice DMF molecule were treated disorderedly over two locations, which were refined isotropically with site occupancy factors of 0.540 and 0.460. In 2, the amide oxygen atom of the bpda ligand was treated disorderedly over two occupied sites with refined site occupancy factors of 0.65 and 0.35, respectively, which were refined isotropically. The guest solvent molecules in the porous structures are disordered and cannot be identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Therefore, the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON was used to remove the diffraction contribution from these solvents, resulting in a set of solvent free diffraction intensities. The calculations indicate the presence of a 512 e/unit cell which can be attributed to two DMF and nine water molecules per formula, and the results are included in the crystallographic CIF file (D calc, F 000, and molecular weight). Carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed geometrically and were refined as riding atoms. Nitrogen-bound hydrogen atoms were first located on difference Fourier maps, and then fixed at the calculated positions and were included in the final refinement. Isotropic displacement parameters of all hydrogen atoms were derived from the parent atoms. The number of guest solvent molecules given in the formula for 1 and 2 was consistent with the single-crystal X-ray diffraction results, respectively. Experimental details for X-ray data collection and the refinements are summarized in Table .

Compounds 1 and 2 were prepared by reacting CoCl2·6H2O, bpda, and the corresponding multicarboxylic acid (2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2thdc) or 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc)) in a DMF/H2O solution under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions (Scheme ). Their molecular structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray structure analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, infrared (IR) spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns confirmed the phase purity of the bulk materials, where the diffraction patterns for these compounds demonstrate a close match between the observed and the calculated patterns (). Obtaining a well-resolved PXRD pattern for 2 was a challenge, but the final data were well-matched with the simulated PXRD patterns, since the lattice solvent molecules might have escaped from the crystal lattice before loading the sample for PXRD measurement.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

Compounds 1 and 2 were prepared by reacting CoCl2⋅6H2O, bpda, and the corresponding multicarboxylic acid (2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2thdc) or 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc)) in a DMF/H2O solution under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions (Scheme ). Their molecular structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray structure analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, infrared (IR) spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns confirmed the phase purity of the bulk materials, where the diffraction patterns for these compounds demonstrate a close match between the observed and the calculated patterns (). Obtaining a well-resolved PXRD pattern for 2 was a challenge, but the final data were well-matched with the simulated PXRD patterns, since the lattice solvent molecules might have escaped from the crystal lattice before loading the sample for PXRD measurement.

elements.content: A thermogravimetric analysis of 1 shows that the lattice and coordinated DMF molecules are eliminated from the networks (calcd. 17.0%; found 17.1%) when the temperature is increased from room temperature to about 320 °C, after which decomposition of the framework occurs (). Compound 2 exhibits a weight loss of 17.0% (calcd. 16.6%) between 30 and 375 °C, corresponding to the loss of lattice water and DMF molecules. The solvent-free framework then begins to decompose as the temperature approaches 394 °C.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and has a 3D porous structure. In the coordination environment of 1, there are two crystallographically independent cobalt centers, both of which adopt an octahedrally {CoN2O4} coordination geometry. One cobalt center, Co(1), is coordinated by one chelating and two monodentate carboxyl groups of three different thdc2– ligands and two trans-positioned bpda ligands while another cobalt center, Co(2), is coordinated by one chelating and one monodentate carboxyl groups of two thdc2– ligands, one DMF molecule, and two trans-positioned bpda ligands (Figure a). It is noteworthy that weak intramolecular CH···O hydrogen bonding interactions formed between the (disordered) coordinated DMF molecules and the monodentate carboxyl groups stabilize the coordination structure (C···O = 3.19–3.31 Å, Table ). There are two independent thdc2– ligands: one serves as a μ3-bridge to link two Co(1) centers, with a syn,syn-bridging carboxyl group, and one Co(2) center, with a chelating carboxyl group, whereas the other one acts as a μ2-bridge to link one Co(1) center, with a chelating carboxyl group, and one Co(2) center, with a monodentate carboxyl group.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[Co2(thdc)2(bpda)2(DMF)]⋅2DMF} n  (1)

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and has a 3D porous structure. In the coordination environment of 1, there are two crystallographically independent cobalt centers, both of which adopt an octahedrally {CoN2O4} coordination geometry. One cobalt center, Co(1), is coordinated by one chelating and two monodentate carboxyl groups of three different thdc2- ligands and two trans-positioned bpda ligands while another cobalt center, Co(2), is coordinated by one chelating and one monodentate carboxyl groups of two thdc2- ligands, one DMF molecule, and two trans-positioned bpda ligands (Figure a). It is noteworthy that weak intramolecular CH⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions formed between the (disordered) coordinated DMF molecules and the monodentate carboxyl groups stabilize the coordination structure (C⋅⋅⋅O = 3.19-3.31 Å, Table ). There are two independent thdc2- ligands: one serves as a μ3-bridge to link two Co(1) centers, with a syn,syn-bridging carboxyl group, and one Co(2) center, with a chelating carboxyl group, whereas the other one acts as a μ2-bridge to link one Co(1) center, with a chelating carboxyl group, and one Co(2) center, with a monodentate carboxyl group.

Two Co(1) centers are bridged by two carboxyl groups from two thdc2– ligands with a Co···Co separation of 3.00 Å, forming a dinuclear [Co2(CO2)4N4] building unit (denoted SBU-1) which resembles a two-blade paddlewheel. The dinuclear SBU-1 and the mononuclear Co(2) center are alternatively connected to each other in two dimensions via the connections of thdc2– ligands to generate an extended neutral 2D layer structure. If the mononuclear Co(2) centers, together with the two accompanied thdc2– ligands, are regarded as linear linkers instead of nodes, the 2D Co–thdc layer can therefore be considered to have a rhomboid grid of 44-topology (), with the three-letter code of sql, in which the distance between the SBU-1···SBU-1 edges is 21.2 Å. The Co–thdc layers are stacked exactly atop each other to give an AAA type of packing, which are pillared by the auxiliary N-tethering bpda ligands with the amide and CO groups (trans-conformation) in an antiparallel orientation to yield a neutral 3D cobalt(II)–organic framework (Figure b), with nanosized open channels viewed along the c axis. From the viewpoint of network topology, each SBU-1 can be viewed as a 6-connected octahedral node, and the Co(2)(thdc)2 moieties and the SBU-1 bound double-bpda-deckered pillars both can be viewed as linear linkes. Meanwhile, the Co(2) bound single-bpda ligands are ruled out from participating in the network topology. Consequently, the entire framework of 1 can be simplified as a uninodal 6-connected pcu topology with a Schäfli notation of 412·63 (Figure c).

The Co-thdc layers are stacked exactly atop each other to give an AAA type of packing, which are pillared by the auxiliary N-tethering bpda ligands with the amide and CO groups (trans-conformation) in an antiparallel orientation to yield a neutral 3D cobalt(II)-organic framework (Figure b), with nanosized open channels viewed along the c axis. From the viewpoint of network topology, each SBU-1 can be viewed as a 6-connected octahedral node, and the Co(2)(thdc)2 moieties and the SBU-1 bound double-bpda-deckered pillars both can be viewed as linear linkes. Meanwhile, the Co(2) bound single-bpda ligands are ruled out from participating in the network topology. Consequently, the entire framework of 1 can be simplified as a uninodal 6-connected pcu  topology with a Schäfli notation of 412⋅63 (Figure c).

elements.content: With the long internode separations of 21.2 Å, large voids are generated within a single framework. In order to stabilize such a porous crystalline material, three such frameworks interpenetrate each other to yield a threefold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure d and ). All of the interpenetrating nets in 1 are exactly superimposed along a single translation direction [1,0,0] with the shortest vector of 10.6 Å, which, when applied 2 times to a single net, generates the entire structure, which can be assigned to the class Ia interpenetration. However, even with this interpenetration, the framework solid 1 generates cage-like cavities with effective dimensions of 3 × 3 Å2 (Figure a) and a large guest can have access to the void space (ca. 619 Å3, equal to 10.5% of the cell volume) in the structure occupied by DMF as a guest molecule. Moderate NH···O hydrogen bonding interactions (N···O = 2.90–3.11 Å, Table ) occurred between the interpenetrating nets, providing further support to stabilize the entire crystal structure (Figure b and ). These net-to-net hydrogen bonds form from the amide hydrogens of the bpda ligands in one net to the carboxylate oxygens of thdc2– ligands in neighboring nets.

elements.content: A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 2 crystallizes in a rhombohedral space group R3̅, and possesses a 3D open framework with large channels. In the coordination environment of 2, the only cobalt center adopts a distorted octahedral {CoN2O4} coordination geometry, composed of two chelating carboxyl groups of two btc3– ligands and two trans-positioned bpda ligands (Figure a). In turn, the C 3 symmetrical btc3– ligand bridges three Co centers where the carboxyl group adopts a symmetrical chelating mode (Figure a). Therefore, the connection of the Co centers and the btc3– ligands in a stoichiometry of 3:2 results in the formation of an extended neutral coordination layer structure having a honeycomb-like 63-hcb topology (), in which these Co···Co edges have a single distance of 9.2 Å. The Co–btc layers are stacked exactly atop each other in an AAA type of sequence, which are pillared by the auxiliary N-tethering bpda ligands having a trans-conformation with an antiparallel orientation of amide and CO groups to yield a neutral 3D cobalt–organic framework, with nanosized, hexagonal channels, when viewed along the c axis (Figure b). From the viewpoint of network topology, each [Co(CO2)2N2] unit can be considered to be a 4-connected square planar node, and the btc ligands can be considered to be 3-connected trigonal planar nodes (Figure a). Therefore, the structure of 2 can be reduced to a new unprecedented binodal (3,4)-connected framework with a (63)2(64·8·10)3 topology (Figure c). The (3,4)-connected net displayed by 2 is aware of coordination polymers [Cu3(btc)2(bpfb)3]·5H2O and [Cu3(btc)2(bpfb)3]·∼12H2O, where bpfb = N,N′-bis(4-pyridylformamide)-1,4-benzene, an isomer of bpda with the design in the amide and CO groups reversed. Further inspection of this new (3,4)-connected net in 2 indicates that there are links between the 4-connected nodes, as well as between the 3- and 4-connected nodes; this is compared with the reported (3,4)-connected nets that are constructed by alternately linking the 3- and 4-connecting nodes.

Crystal Structure of {[Co3(btc)2(bpda)3]⋅2DMF⋅9H2O} n  (2)

A single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 2 crystallizes in a rhombohedral space group R3̅, and possesses a 3D open framework with large channels. In the coordination environment of 2, the only cobalt center adopts a distorted octahedral {CoN2O4} coordination geometry, composed of two chelating carboxyl groups of two btc3- ligands and two trans-positioned bpda ligands (Figure a). In turn, the C 3 symmetrical btc3- ligand bridges three Co centers where the carboxyl group adopts a symmetrical chelating mode (Figure a). Therefore, the connection of the Co centers and the btc3- ligands in a stoichiometry of 3:2 results in the formation of an extended neutral coordination layer structure having a honeycomb-like 63-hcb topology (), in which these Co⋅⋅⋅Co edges have a single distance of 9.2 Å. The Co-btc layers are stacked exactly atop each other in an AAA type of sequence, which are pillared by the auxiliary N-tethering bpda ligands having a trans-conformation with an antiparallel orientation of amide and CO groups to yield a neutral 3D cobalt-organic framework, with nanosized, hexagonal channels, when viewed along the c axis (Figure b). From the viewpoint of network topology, each [Co(CO2)2N2] unit can be considered to be a 4-connected square planar node, and the btc ligands can be considered to be 3-connected trigonal planar nodes (Figure a). Therefore, the structure of 2 can be reduced to a new unprecedented binodal (3,4)-connected framework with a (63)2(64⋅8⋅10)3 topology (Figure c). The (3,4)-connected net displayed by 2 is aware of coordination polymers [Cu3(btc)2(bpfb)3]⋅5H2O and [Cu3(btc)2(bpfb)3]⋅~12H2O, where bpfb = N,N'-bis(4-pyridylformamide)-1,4-benzene, an isomer of bpda with the design in the amide and CO groups reversed. Further inspection of this new (3,4)-connected net in 2 indicates that there are links between the 4-connected nodes, as well as between the 3- and 4-connected nodes; this is compared with the reported (3,4)-connected nets that are constructed by alternately linking the 3- and 4-connecting nodes.

elements.content: It should be noted that the voids in the framework are filled via the mutual interpenetration of two more independent frameworks, generating a threefold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure d and ). When viewed along the crystallographic [2,1,1] direction, the interpenetration of equivalent nets in 2 are related by a single translation vector of 12.6 Å (), hence, being a class Ia interpenetration. Despite this threefold interpenetration, there is still sufficient guest accessible void space (ca. 1409 Å3, equal to 24.0% of the cell volume) in the structure occupied by disordered guest molecules which could not be successfully modeled in the crystallographic refinement. A perspective view reveals that the threefold mutually interpenetrating nets generate two sets of cage-like cavities with effective dimensions of approximately 3 × 3 and 3 × 8 Å2, respectively (Figure a). In addition, the structure is stabilized by moderate NH···O hydrogen bonding interactions between the interpenetrating nets (N···O = 3.29 and 3.30 Å, Table ). These net-to-net hydrogen bonds form from the amide hydrogens of the bpda ligands in one net to the carboxylate oxygens of the btc3– ligands and to the amind oxygens of the bpda ligands in neighboring nets (Figure b and ).

elements.content: In this work, the two bpda-based pillared-layer structures 1 and 2 show threefold interpenetration characteristics, with a 412·63-pcu and a (63)2(64·8·10)3 network topology, respectively. Our previous studies have shown that the {[Zn2(bdc)2(bpda)2]·2.5DMF·1.5H2O} n is a twofold interpenetration of a 412·63-pcu net. It is interesting to note that a similar trend exists in these 3D pillared-layered frameworks. As shown in Table which lists 3D porous frameworks composed of metal–carboxylate layers and N-tethering pillars, a small pillar (e.g., dabco, 2.6 Å for N-to-N distance), in general, leads to a noninterpenetrated framework while a larger pillar (e.g., bpy, 7.0 Å for N-to-N distance) shows mostly doubly or even triply interpenetration characteristics. However, pillar length is not the only factor that can affect the degree of interpenetration. Other factors, such as the mesh size of the metal–carboxylate layer, also have an impact on the degree of interpenetration. For example, compound [M2(bdc)2(L) x ]·G (M = Zn, Co, Cd; L = bpy, bpe, bpda; x = 1, 2) having M–bdc sql-layer with mesh dimensions of approximately 11.0 × 11.0 Å2 exhibits a twofold interpenetration, even in the case of larger pillars such as bpe (9.3 Å for N-to-N distance) and bpda (15.8 Å for N-to-N distance). In comparison, sql-layers of M–ndc, M–3,3′-bpdc, and M–4,4′-bpdc having mesh dimensions of about 13.1 × 13.1 Å2, 13.8 × 13.8 Å2, and 15.2 × 15.2 Å2, respectively, are generally involved in the formation of porous frameworks with a maximum of a threefold interpenetration, even when relatively smaller bpy pillars are used. Switching to [M2(D-cam)2(L)]·G (M = Zn, Co; L = dabco, bpy, bpe), the bent structure of the D-cam ligand leads to nearly closed mesh size within the M–D-cam layer which avoids the occurrence of interpenetration and thus forms a noninterpenetrated framework. For the larger pillar of bpda and bpfb, a pillar length of approximately 15.8 Å, in principle, favors the formation of a fourfold interpenetration framework. However, a limited one- to threefold interpenetration framework is formed, which is mostly attributed to the influence of the mesh size of the metal–carboxylate layer and the hydrogen-bonding behavior of the amide groups. On the other hand, topological control over the interpenetration in MOFs is observed in the 6-connected 446108-nets [Cd2(1,4-chdc)2(bpda)]·4H2O16 and [Co2(D-cam)2(bpypip)]·1.5H2O; the self-penetrated framework protects them from interpenetration.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

In this work, the two bpda-based pillared-layer structures 1 and 2 show threefold interpenetration characteristics, with a 412⋅63-pcu and a (63)2(64⋅8⋅10)3 network topology, respectively. Our previous studies have shown that the {[Zn2(bdc)2(bpda)2]⋅2.5DMF⋅1.5H2O} n  is a twofold interpenetration of a 412⋅63-pcu net. It is interesting to note that a similar trend exists in these 3D pillared-layered frameworks. As shown in Table  which lists 3D porous frameworks composed of metal-carboxylate layers and N-tethering pillars, a small pillar (e.g., dabco, 2.6 Å for N-to-N distance), in general, leads to a noninterpenetrated framework while a larger pillar (e.g., bpy, 7.0 Å for N-to-N distance) shows mostly doubly or even triply interpenetration characteristics. However, pillar length is not the only factor that can affect the degree of interpenetration. Other factors, such as the mesh size of the metal-carboxylate layer, also have an impact on the degree of interpenetration. For example, compound [M2(bdc)2(L) x ]⋅G (M = Zn, Co, Cd; L = bpy, bpe, bpda; x = 1, 2) having M-bdc sql-layer with mesh dimensions of approximately 11.0 × 11.0 Å2 exhibits a twofold interpenetration, even in the case of larger pillars such as bpe (9.3 Å for N-to-N distance) and bpda (15.8 Å for N-to-N distance). In comparison, sql-layers of M-ndc, M-3,3'-bpdc, and M-4,4'-bpdc having mesh dimensions of about 13.1 × 13.1 Å2, 13.8 × 13.8 Å2, and 15.2 × 15.2 Å2, respectively, are generally involved in the formation of porous frameworks with a maximum of a threefold interpenetration, even when relatively smaller bpy pillars are used. Switching to [M2(D-cam)2(L)]⋅G (M = Zn, Co; L = dabco, bpy, bpe), the bent structure of the D-cam ligand leads to nearly closed mesh size within the M-D-cam layer which avoids the occurrence of interpenetration and thus forms a noninterpenetrated framework. For the larger pillar of bpda and bpfb, a pillar length of approximately 15.8 Å, in principle, favors the formation of a fourfold interpenetration framework. However, a limited one- to threefold interpenetration framework is formed, which is mostly attributed to the influence of the mesh size of the metal-carboxylate layer and the hydrogen-bonding behavior of the amide groups. On the other hand, topological control over the interpenetration in MOFs is observed in the 6-connected 446108-nets [Cd2(1,4-chdc)2(bpda)]⋅4H2O16 and [Co2(D-cam)2(bpypip)]⋅1.5H2O; the self-penetrated framework protects them from interpenetration.

The findings reported herein demonstrate that, in the design of pillared-layer porous MOFs, the mesh size of the metal–caroxylate layer, in addition to the length of the pillar, plays a key role in controlling the degree of interpenetration of MOFs. To prove the concept, two threefold interpenetration pillared-layer porous MOFs were successfully synthesized and the results of their structural analyses perfectly support this proposed relationship.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The findings reported herein demonstrate that, in the design of pillared-layer porous MOFs, the mesh size of the metal-caroxylate layer, in addition to the length of the pillar, plays a key role in controlling the degree of interpenetration of MOFs. To prove the concept, two threefold interpenetration pillared-layer porous MOFs were successfully synthesized and the results of their structural analyses perfectly support this proposed relationship.

Synthesis of {[Co2(thdc)2(bpda)2(DMF)]⋅2DMF} n  (1)

A mixture of CoCl2⋅6H2O (24.0 mg, 0.10 mmol), 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2thdc, 17.2 mg, 0.10 mmol), bpda (31.9 mg, 0.10 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 7 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bomb and heated at 120 °C for 72 h and then slowly cooled to 30 °C. Reddish prismatic crystals of 1 were isolated on a filter, washed with water, and then dried in air (29.4 mg, yield 46%). Anal. Calcd for C57H53Co2N11O15S2: C, 52.10; H, 4.07; N, 11.72%. Found: C, 51.51; H, 4.25; N, 11.83%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3264 (m), 3174 (w), 3078 (m), 2929 (w), 1683 (s), 1657 (m), 1595 (s), 1525 (s), 1423 (m), 1384 (s), 1329 (m), 1295 (m), 1260 (w), 1211 (m), 1098 (w), 1018 (m), 888 (w), 868 (w), 836 (m), 770 (m), 713 (m), 682 (w), 663 (w), 603 (m), 539 (m), 498 (m).

Synthesis of {[Co3(btc)2(bpda)3]⋅2DMF⋅9H2O} n  (2)

A mixture of CoCl2⋅6H2O (23.8 mg, 0.10 mmol), 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc, 14.7 mg, 0.070 mmol), bpda (31.9 mg, 0.10 mmol), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 7 mL), and H2O (0.5 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr acid digestion bomb and heated at 80 °C for 72 h and then slowly cooled to 30 °C. Reddish hexagonal prismatic crystals of 2 were isolated on a filter, washed with water, and dried in air (20.3 mg, yield 37%). Anal. Calcd for C78H80N14O29Co3: C, 50.52; H, 4.35; N, 10.57%. Found: C, 50.43; H, 3.95; N, 10.60%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3356 (b), 2927 (w), 1686 (s), 1621 (w), 1594 (s), 1550 (w), 1503 (s), 1453 (m), 1425 (m), 1380 (s), 1331 (s), 1261 (m), 1212 (m), 1100 (s), 1019 (m), 885 (w), 873 (w), 842 (s), 761 (m), 735 (s), 663 (w), 609 (m), 541 (m).

cln_elements.content:
A thermogravimetric analysis of 1 shows that the lattice and coordinated DMF molecules are eliminated from the networks (calcd. 17.0%; found 17.1%) when the temperature is increased from room temperature to about 320 °C, after which decomposition of the framework occurs (). Compound 2 exhibits a weight loss of 17.0% (calcd. 16.6%) between 30 and 375 °C, corresponding to the loss of lattice water and DMF molecules. The solvent-free framework then begins to decompose as the temperature approaches 394 °C.

It should be noted that the voids in the framework are filled via the mutual interpenetration of two more independent frameworks, generating a threefold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure d and ). When viewed along the crystallographic [2,1,1] direction, the interpenetration of equivalent nets in 2 are related by a single translation vector of 12.6 Å (), hence, being a class Ia interpenetration. Despite this threefold interpenetration, there is still sufficient guest accessible void space (ca. 1409 Å3, equal to 24.0% of the cell volume) in the structure occupied by disordered guest molecules which could not be successfully modeled in the crystallographic refinement. A perspective view reveals that the threefold mutually interpenetrating nets generate two sets of cage-like cavities with effective dimensions of approximately 3 × 3 and 3 × 8 Å2, respectively (Figure a). In addition, the structure is stabilized by moderate NH···O hydrogen bonding interactions between the interpenetrating nets (N···O = 3.29 and 3.30 Å, Table ). These net-to-net hydrogen bonds form from the amide hydrogens of the bpda ligands in one net to the carboxylate oxygens of the btc3– ligands and to the amind oxygens of the bpda ligands in neighboring nets (Figure b and ).

Crystal structure of 1: (a) the coordination environment of the two crystallographic independent cobalt centers; (b) view of the 3D structure along the c axis; (c) a single 6-connected pcu net, with the [Co2(CO2)4N4] building units as 6-connected octahedral nodes (green balls), and the Co(2)(thdc)2 moieties and the double-bpda-deckered pillars both as linear linkes (green lines); (d) topological representation of the threefold interpenetration of pcu net.
